#Text=Fort St John
#Text=Fort
#Text=St.
#Text=John
#Text=is the second-largest settlement along the Alaska Highway .
#Text=The city of 20,000 people ( 2016 ) is in the northeastern British Columbia , approximately 382 km south of Fort Nelson and 75 km north of Dawson Creek .
#Text=Fort St. John is the oldest European-established settlement in present-day British Columbia .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Fort St. John is a retail , service and industrial centre .
#Text=The province 's oil and gas industry is centred in the city .
#Text=Forestry has become more important to the city since the opening of an oriented strand board plant in 2005 .
#Text=Much wood of the is exported to the United States .
#Text=Agriculture has been the mainstay of the economy servicing and providing a market for the upland prairies .
#Text=History
#Text=Over the years the community has been moved a number of times for varying economic reasons .
#Text=The present location is thought to be its sixth .
#Text=The original trading post built in the area was named Rocky Mountain House ( not to be confused with the modern Alberta town by that name ) .
#Text=It was established one year after Sir Alexander Mackenzie explored the area in 1793 .
#Text=One of a series of forts along the Peace River constructed to service the fur trade , it was southwest of the present site of Fort St. John .
#Text=The Dunneza and Sikanni First Nations used it as a trading post .
#Text=It was also used as a supply depot for further expeditions into the territory .
#Text=The fort closed in 1805 .
#Text=Fort d'Epinette was built in 1806 by the North West Company .
#Text=It was renamed Fort St. John in 1821 following the purchase of the North West Company by the Hudson 's Bay Company .
#Text=This fort was about 500 m downstream from the mouth of the Beatton River , which at that time was known as the Pine River ( d'epinette in French ) .
#Text=It was shut down in 1823 .
#Text=The site was designated a National Historic Site of Canada in 1958 .
#Text=After a lapse of nearly 40 years , Fort St. John was reopened in 1860 on the south side of the Peace River , directly south of the present community .
#Text=It was moved in 1872 by Francis Work Beatton directly across the river .
#Text=This community lasted until 1925 when the river ceased to be the main avenue of transportation and the fort was moved closer to where settlers were establishing homesteads .
#Text=The new town was constructed at Fish Creek , northwest of the present community , on the new trail to Fort Nelson .
#Text=It did not shut down until 1975 .
#Text=In 1928 , C.M. Finch moved his general store to two quarters of land where he also built a government building to house the land , telegraph and post offices .
#Text=The present site for the town was firmly established after he donated 5 acres ( 20,000 m ² ) for a Roman Catholic Church and additional land for a hospital .
#Text=Climate
#Text=Fort St. John , on the upland prairies north of the Peace River , experiences a cold humid continental climate ( close to subarctic ) , with cold winters and warm summers .

#Text=Although winters can be frigid , the area has milder winters than much of the rest of Canada ( especially considering its relatively northerly latitude ) due to the influence of the nearby Rocky Mountains .
#Text=They tend to block Arctic air masses coming in from the north/northwest , although they can certainly still penetrate the area .

#Text=Fort St. John uses Mountain Standard Time all year ( same as Pacific Daylight Time in summer ) , and because of its northerly latitude experiences short daylight hours in winter and long daylight hours in summer .
#Text=Fort St. John is one of the sunniest places in the province , especially in the winter and spring .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Twice a week , BC Bus North provides service from Prince George via Dawson Creek to Fort St John with a weekly connection to Fort Nelson .
#Text=By car
#Text=Fort St John can be reached by driving north from Dawson Creek or south from Fort Nelson on Highway 97 .
#Text=By air
#Text=The only commercial airport between Dawson Creek and Fort Nelson is the Fort St. John Airport ( CYXJ ) a few kilometres east of the city .
#Text=The two-runway airport has Air Canada Jazz , WestJet and other smaller airlines such as Central Mountain Air with regularly scheduled flights and North Cariboo Air providing chartered flights .
#Text=Get around
#Text=BC Transit provides transportation around town .
#Text=Within the city the streets are laid out in a grid pattern .
#Text=The main streets are the north-south 100 Street and the east-west 100 Avenue .
#Text=See
#Text=Fort St. John North Peace Museum , 9323 100 St. , ☏ +1 250-787-0430 , ✉ fsjnpmuseum@fsjmail.com .
#Text=M - Sa 9AM-5PM .
#Text=Ths museum tells the story of the Fort St. John region including First Nations ' settlements , the fur trade , agricultural settlement , the growth of the town , and the Alaska Highway .
#Text=Adults $ 6 , seniors ( 65+ ) $ 5 , students $ 4 , children 5 & under free .
#Text=North Peace Cultural Centre , 10015 100 Ave , ☏ +1 877-785-1992 .
#Text=Gallery : Tu - Sa 10AM-5PM .
#Text=In the centre of town , it houses the Fort St. John Public Library , a theatre , and the Peace Gallery North Art Gallery .
#Text=Every August , the Great Canadian Welding Competition is held in Fort St. John , which sees welding artists fill Centennial Park creating statues on the year 's theme .
#Text=In January the annual High on Ice Winter Carnival has a frozen Centennial Park filled with ice sculptors competing and other special winter-related activities occurring around town .
#Text=Do

#Text=Centennial Park includes the Fort St. John North Peace Museum , the North Peace Leisure Pool , the North Peace Arena ( home of the Fort St. John Huskies ) , a separate arena for children , an 8-sheet curling rink , as well as an outdoor water park and speed skating oval .
#Text=Other parks in the area include the city-maintained Fish Creek Community Forest , and about 10 km ( 6.2 mi ) northwest of town the Beatton Provincial Park and Charlie Lake Provincial Park .

#Text=The city 's main recreation centre is the Pomeroy Sport Centre , a three-storey public facility with two National Hockey League-sized ice rinks , an indoor near-Olympic-sized long track speed skating oval , and a 340 meter long walking track ( the " Northern Vac Track " ) .
